plist.p: Good morning to everybody. Many thanks for being here for our Year End Results presentation. As you can see, we are here with first of all the Investor Relations team, then the Deputy CEO and the CFO, so we will be more than happy to answer all your questions at the end of the presentation. We are responsible for claiming – we are all the staff is here.

We will talk of the year end results but before talking of the year end results as usual we want have a short executive summary. 2007 results confirm our group capability in terms of delivering results in a challenging market environment. The net income is 6.6 billion; normalized, and then we will explain what does mean normalized, 7.3 billion. We have a very strong EVA generation; it's 8% up year on year to 2.6 billion.

The earnings per share normalized; again, that means excluding integration cost, capital gain on Mediobanca, one-off impacts of the tax reform in Italy and Germany and the PPA, will be €0.55 per share. That means that we are in line with what we have always said. The earnings per share without Capitalia would be €0.62, significantly more than the original plan, 17% higher than the previous year.

Operating profit is up by 11.4% year on year. We had quite a good growth in commercial banking thanks to our diversification coming from all the different areas of the group and this is more than offset in the markdown in MIB markets.

The core Tier 1 after the year end results because of PPA the cleaning up also of balance sheet in Capitalia withdrawal rights we have in our books is 5.83%, slightly above 2006 despite acquisitions and as I've said the Capitalia withdrawal rights. This has also been achieved thanks to organic capital generation. So also all the issues on the need for incoming capital and some are completely out of the screen after this number.

Asset quality, net impaired loans were down by 15% year on year. It's quite a significant improvement in terms of quality of our balance sheet. The coverage ratios are up by 3% year on year to 54.5%. You will see later on also the fact that the lower provisions here are due to the fact that we had cash in, so our real payments we received from customer in

Capitalia, right-sizing there is quite quick and above expectations, paving the way for higher than anticipated synergies, 1.3 billion integration costs booked in '07. And this is higher than the original plan only due to the fact that we have 7,800 people more than expected that are leaving. So we decided to book all these one-off costs in 2007 to speed up the integration process.

We'll talk of the results, some key topics, and updates since we think that there are some topics that must be specifically addressed; Capitalia integration and synergies focus and a short outlook on 2008.

Starting from the results, here we have the overall numbers: total revenues 29.6 billion; operating costs 16.3; operating profit 13.3; integration costs 1.3; so we had a pre-tax profit of 10.5. Net income for the Group pre-PPA is 6.6; 62 million of PPA. The net income is 6.5. Normalized, as I said before taking away the integration costs that after tax are 840 million; the capital gain on Mediobanca, 550 million; the one-off impact of the tax reform in Italy and Germany, 360 million; and the PPA would be 7.3 billion.

What about the 2007 results vis-à-vis the expectation? The earnings per share pro forma is €0.50. There are 2 basis points of the tax – Italian reform. This is a tax deferred asset that had a lower value. That means that in the future, we will pay lower taxes, but we had to book the one-off costs in the first year. It's exactly the same for Germany, 1 basis point; PPA, 0.5 basis point; 2 basis points on integration cost, and net of the gain of Mediobanca, we go up to the €0.55. When we were talking at the end of the third quarter, we were still foreseeing €0.56. €0.55 is quite clearly €0.01 less, but as we know, in the fourth quarter the spread then we will talk specifically on investment banking enlarged quite significantly. So, we had a negative mark to market in the portfolio, indicated in the portfolio. But overall, the rest of the bank performed better than expected, so we are where we are.

Without Capitalia, we are at You remember that the original plan was €0.56. So, we think those results are pretty good. The core Tier 1 ratio is 5.83. We had 9 basis points coming from the withdrawal rights of Capitalia, so we have the treasury shares in our portfolio. And we have acquired ATF at 28 basis points. So, summing up these two numbers, we are exactly in line with the plan, which was 6.2, again despite the overall market turmoil and the fact that risk weighted assets grew up more than expected, so also in terms of capital generation. I think that we are doing very, very well. Dividend per share, yesterday the Board has approved a proposal to the AGM a dividend per share of €0.26, which is also a clear demonstration on the confidence we have on the strength of the group.

Comparisons versus the previous year; I think that this is quite important. The total revenues went up by 5.1%. I think that it is better to be focused on the '06 comparison of costs and the perimeters unless we have a change of perimeters. The operating costs are flat, 0.4% up, and despite the significant branch opening process we had in Central and Eastern Europe. So it's also a good demonstration on the capabilities the group has in terms of controlling the cost. So the operating profits are above the previous year of 11.4%.

I would like to stress the fact that also if we compared the first quarter '07 vis-à-vis the fourth quarter '06 in terms of operating profit, we are flat. And considering the market conditions, I would say that this is not at all a bad result. We are quite happy with that. We have also to consider the fact; we'll talk later on of that; that all the impact for us in terms of the evaluation of the credit trading portfolio are in the trading profit, while we know that many other players have moved their portfolio in the banking book so they are not booking these numbers in the operating results. So I think that this is quite important. I will talk later on our investment banking. I want stress the fact that we have not changed any accounting standard. This is a key element and then we'll talk about the valuation process. But I think this is a very, very important element for you to understand our results.

So talking of net write-downs; we had a reduction in the fourth quarter. We are flat on the previous year. This is based on cash recoveries, mainly in investment banking and to say quite clearly, the cost of investment banking has been positive because we had the repayment by customers. These repayments are mainly concentrated in Germany; this is quite an important topic. Integration costs are significantly higher than the previous year. As I said before, we have decided to book all the costs this year also for the higher and higher than expected retirement, the early retirement acceptance by our employees. So we go down to what we have seen before in terms of net income and normalized net income. The cost/income ratio is 55%, 2.6% lower than the previous year. So I would say that these are not bad at all numbers.

Talking of the different revenue lines, we had very good revenue lines, good revenue growth both in net interest income and net commissions. I'd like to stress the fact that also net commissions are higher than the previous year in the fourth quarter; and quite clearly, this is not an easy environment for such kind of revenues, so the trading income are negative and we will see afterwards what about the credit rating portfolio. This is really an amount negative we had was due to the enlargement of spreads. As we know the enlargement of spreads is continuing also in the first quarter of this year and in a quite significant way.

You are business or market people so you know better than me what is the condition in this spread environment. We can discuss quite a lot on the reasons why there are these spread divisions. We have that this is mainly a liquidity issue more than a credit risk issue and because quite clearly the spreads are so significant that in terms of credit spreads are not justifiable. Today we are AAA. AAA in terms of rating today, asset with the spread that is larger than junk bond 12 months ago or significantly larger than junk bonds. So quite clearly, there is a dislocation of the market that is related to a liquidity topic more than a credit risk topic. How these spreads will move is unforeseeable, so this is clearly one of the main issues all of us we do have. We have to manage properly this position and meanwhile to continue to be focused on all the rest of the activities.

What about the revenue growth in the different business lines? It has been quite good everywhere. Quite clearly we have this negative change in MIB due to the structured credit impact, minus 431 million in the year '07, partially offset by strong results in the other business lines. We have an increase into the asset management; quite clearly asset management in the other areas which is affected by the actual market turmoil. All the other commercial lines are doing quite well, starting from Central/Eastern European region with close to 17% growth, going to private banking, retail, and corporate. But later on we'll talk more deeply and also I'm sure that you will have questions for our colleagues.

Costs, as you can see, we have a reduction in staff expenses also in the fourth quarter due to the reductions we're having in terms of total people and also due to the fact that the variable compensation in MIB is lower but clearly following the market turmoil. Other administrative expenses are going up. We have split this year the region where we have increase of 9.5% in constant FX and Perimeter, driven by the opening of branches, so we are adding many in Turkey, Russia, and Hungary.

As you know, we have significant plan in terms of opening new branches. The timeframe for the repayment in the opening of these branches is quite short; so we are sure that this is the right way to go in these growing markets. The rest of the group is up by 3.6%, mainly driven by project developments in Holding. For instance, Basel II is a quite an expensive project that will have a significant positive impact in terms of the reduction of capital and then we have higher cost for outsourcing IT and back office, mainly in Germany. As we know, we have outsourced the payment system to Postbank we are outsourced the GBS business.
Depreciation is down year on year, thanks to the fact that we have completed in 2006 the ICT system depreciation in Bank Austria.

What about the non-operating items? We have 753 million provision for risk and charges; 1.3 billion for integration costs; 2.5 the net write-downs; then 1.7 net income for investments or the main capital gain are related to Mediobanca, 603 million; Custodian Business in Germany, 292; Indexchange, 138; and other non-strategic holding by 315. The tax rate is likely higher than expected due to the one-off effect of German and Italy tax reforms and the adjusted tax rate would be 26.7; and we have minorities and the PPA.

I think that this chart is very, very important because it gives you the strengths, the main idea of the strengths of the group, which is related to our diversification I would say both in terms of business lines and in terms of geographies. Maybe the graphical diversification is not very visible here because as you know, we are organized by divisions so we are leading the group by division and more and more within the division by business clients. For instance in the retail division, we have outsourced financing; therefore this is a quite important product.

In the corporate business, we have leasing and global transactional banking but I think that this shows you the clients in terms of diversification and also the fact that all the divisions were very positive marginal RARORAC, which is also quite important. Despite the market turmoil, investment banking also in '07 had a positive marginal RARORAC of 10.5%, which means – net profit generation on the cost of capital. So I think that this is a key indicator of the strengths of the group.

Retail, quite clearly has the major delta year on year because of construction in process in Germany and in Austria is a going ahead quite well; so a positive EVA also in Germany retail, which is something that I would say is pretty good you see in the market. So I am looking for the best of that. I think it's again also quite important.

An update on the key topics, which are the four key topics I think are and as a stoplight; the first one is capital and funding; so finally we hope that this rumor continuously going on that the need of a capital increases would be completed right after this presentation.

MIB division performances, which again is also quite important because: one, a week ago there was in London a rumor on that fact that we are having a 5 billion write-down in the structure of credit portfolios; so again I hope that everything will be clarified. Purchase price allocation, which is quite important because we will talk of Capitalia and the balance sheet of Capitalia. As you know we can talk of cleaning out he balance sheet of Capitalia goes in this voice so it is not in the profit and loss but is in the equity and finally the asset quality.

Capital and funding; here we have a comparison on December '06 – December '07. I'd like to draw you attention just for a second on the footnote because when we are talking of December '06 capital risk within asset and ratios is not pro forma, therefore they exclude Capitalia. EVA includes Capitalia. This is important because unless we would compare and it is important for you to know.

EVA, we went up by 8%, which is quite good, with the marginal RARORAC up by 16 basis points. Since the delta EVA is the financial number which is more related to total shareholder returns and for us it's important, the return we have capable to generate to you is a key number, so this is a very important base for all our and hopefully your analysis. The core capital is significantly up; the total capital as well. Total risk weighted assets grew significantly both for organic growth and capital integration. What is important is fact that the Core Tier 1 is at 5.83 despite the acquisitions we have made, many at the Tier 1 levels, and the Capitalia withdrawal rights.

Tier 1 ratio is 6.54. The core Tier I ratio and hopefully I will not have to explain again is an internal number. As you know, it is not a regulatory number and is a number where we have defined a target in order to go back to AA rating. Then as we know perfectly, there are players with a lower core Tier 1 ratio with AA because it's related to many different factors: for instance, how the integration process is going because a bank that has just made an integration where operationally there is a desire than a bank that has not made an integration. So there are many different factors on which the rating is calculated. But again, our capital generation has been quite – the total capital ratio is above 10%.

What about of '08? In '08, quite clearly, we have activities that will absorb capital, namely the organic growth in risk weighted assets, which is always quite important; the squeeze-out in Germany and Austria; and the acquisition of Ukrsotsbank that we have finalized in January. We have activities that we know will generate capital. The net profit returns remain very clearly. The disposal of Generali that if I remember correctly is the 5th or 8th of December, we let them with the expiry of the convertible bond; the disposal of BPH and the disposal of Capitalia branches. So we are considering all these things and we know that we will be in line with our expectation because we have this organic capital generation.

Talking of liquidity, in terms of short term liquidity position, we have a sound and comfortable short term liquidity position for us. The liquidity position is the one month liquidity position, further improving in the first months of '08. If we would consider 100 as a base at the year end, at the end of February we are at 180. So, we continue to improve this position.

We had a significant growth of the intragroup flows, which is quite important because it gives an idea on the how effective is the group cash pooling. And finally, the short term funding base is very, very diversified both in terms of instruments and in terms of the geographical base. So to date, the short term liquidity is not any more an issue as a matter, just to be clear. So, I think that this is quite an important topic.

The medium and long term funding, also here we are quite diversified both in terms of instruments and in terms of currencies. Clearly the euro is the main currency we are using. It is 84% of our total funding activity. So it's very clearly the main currency which we are working. As you can see also our resources are very well diversified. And we have not – so we have a very balanced structure on the different areas. Mainly is the institutional area, which is the main source for us.

We have been able also to go to the market in a quite positive way. In the second half of '07, we issued a 2 billion subordinated loan, which has been well accepted by market. And in February '08, we went to the market with 2.5 billion senior bond – 5 year senior bond. Also that is quite important; we had demand of 6.4 billion; so it is quite important in terms of acceptance of the market.

The balance sheet is not mismatched. This is also quite important. The liquidity ratio limit is above 0.90. This is also quite important because to date having back a liquid market in the short term, there could be a mismatch that in theory is favorable in terms of economics for sure will increase the liquidity . We continue to have very sound policy also in this perspective.

Talking of the MIB performance, quite clearly this business line has been hit by the market turmoil. This was quite natural. I would say that comparing with our peers, we have performed quite well. The first half has been a record performance and the second half has been hindered by the weakness in the structured credit portfolio with strong results in the other business lines.

Structured Credit; there has been a significant spread widening impacting the diversified and high quality 15.8 ABS portfolio. 98% of this portfolio is investment grade. We have very low exposure to the US. It is the more or less 10% of the total portfolio. We have negligible US subprime; it is more or less 1% of the total portfolio. So again, we don't know how to say that subprime is not an issue for us. The portfolio is marked to market with strict price verification process. There is a chart on what is the valuation system we have and the profit and loss is impacted primarily on a mark-to-market basis versus incurred losses. We will provide also for you the number on that.

If you ask me what can happen in terms of mark to market, I'm unable to answer because quite clearly the enlargement of spread is still having a negative impact. This is completely clear to all of us. I think the examination finance plan that's in your city. So there is or maybe even as a secondary school. So it's quite clear to me – to all of us.

If you ask me what is foreign capital on the market, if I would able to answer, I would be a very rich man. I'm not so it is quite clear that it is not possible to answer. So and if you have a crystal ball, please give it to me; we will try to use it.

We have a very modest exposure to the other critical areas; 5.1 billion our sponsored conduits, down by 70% since June '07. We have no losses and have been fully consolidated by the year end. In the 5.83 of Core Tier 1, there is a full consolidation of the conduit. There is only one conduit that has not been consolidated. It is Bavaria TRR because the 21st of February, as we have said to you in June, is expired, so it is not there anymore. We have less then 75 million net exposure to third party SIV. We don't have SIV sponsored by us. 24 million direct exposure to monoliners and the LBO underwriting portfolio features high quality credit stories. We'll spend some words also on that.

Talking of markets, as you know, the organization in investment banking is market investment banking and principal investment. Talking of markets, here we have the performance in '07,+ the full year. As you can see, revenues went down by 33%. We have negative results in the fourth quarter vis-à-vis positive results in the fourth quarter of '06. You can see how has been the performance in fixed income currencies in this business line and the equities line year on year and the structured credit performance year on year. We had a positive performance in '06 and a negative performance in '07.

The realized losses in the fourth quarter have been 149 million. The mark-to-market negative is 277 and the other is negative by 50 million. It's only related to the spread widening; more than 90% are held for trading of this portfolio. So it is clearly having – and we have not changed any classifications. So this is exactly what we had at the beginning of the year; is a negative mark to market that if the spread will go back, quite clearly it's not easy to say when this can happen, will have a positive impact.

Portfolio composition, as I said before, the total portfolio is 15.8, for us gross and net is exactly the same because we don't have any hedging. We have made, as you can imagine, a significant analysis on the reporting of all our competitors. Being one of the latest, we have this advantage; and then have to comment also why we are one of the latest because the number of information we have to provide is dramatically higher than for any other country because this is country driven, the level of information. And we have to do the consolidation line by line for all the companies of the group, while for instance in other countries is accepted the suite consolidated concept.

As you can imagine having I think 1,300 companies, many are nearly 1,300, more than that, companies to book consolidated line by line is something which is very, very complex and then you have all the reporting. It is not a matter that we are lazy, not at all. The problem is that we have a very significant set of information. But this brings us also some advantages because we have the opportunity to analyze the reporting of all our competitors. And in many cases, we have seen that there are significant portfolios that are in the banking book today.

There is no explanation on the structure of the portfolio or not always is this completely clear. And in many cases there are hedges, so we know that there have been significant losses on the fact that the correlation went past. And so, the hedging strategy was not paying the hedging losses on the hedging side. We don't have any idea. This is also the reason why we are so low exposure to the monoliners we got the hedging strategy in many cases has been on the hedging activity with them. So for us, gross and net is exactly the same.

Out of this 15.8 billion of total market value, 1.7 is US and of this, 164 million is subprime. As I said before, there are no hedging risks. A very significant portion, close to 90% is still today we have with people at 'AA' rating. 97.6% is investment grade, also this is I think is quite important.

In terms of the valuation, we have the front office valuation, as you can imagine; and then we have an independent price verification process, which is used to value the structured credit portfolio. The lack of liquidity following the turmoil in the credit markets has further highlighted the importance of an independent pricing methodology for structured credit products. What we do, HVB and MIB use an independent price verification process to provide an independent check of front office prices. On a monthly basis, market risk controller compares prices from the front office with those of leading data providers and external counterparts. Positions are also ranked based on data sources and then on top of that to take account of potential liquidity constraints, a fair value adjustment may be also added. Results are analyzed and reviewed with the front office.

The combination of independent price valuation and fair value adjustment is used to generate prudent valuations. I think this is quite important and the results are important because to give you an idea on the quality of this valuation; in January, we have sold 24 million of the US subprime exposure. At the end of December, the number was 154. At the end of the February, it is 118, so it is even lower than the 164. We have sold 24 million without negative impact on the profit and loss. That means exactly that the independent price valuation works pretty well.

I think that this is again quite important. We have being always consistent because at the end of August, we have communicated the 354 million; so this is your risk. I want to stress that this is a stock because this morning I received a question but the 154 million are the losses not this is a stock we had at the year end, so which is different and today is even lower.

Conduits, as I said before, the conduits are fully consolidated. Bavaria TRR, completely expired the 21st of February; there is no meaningful impact on quarter one. The profit and loss impact in '07 of the overall conduits has been close €20 million; so it is completely negligible. Again I think this was one of the main worries when we are talking one day and in fact there was a rumor that we would have other 40 million – 40 billion, I don't remember what. Again, these are the numbers that are fully consolidated. So, there is not any more any potential worries; we didn't have any even before but I think the matter is completely clear.
SIV, today we are 74 million in third-party SIVs. Profit and loss impact in '07 has been 100 million. Also on that, we have been very conservative if in the future, there will be any cash back.

Monoliners; we do not use monoliners in hedging strategies. So we don't have CDS with monoliners as a direct counterpart. The direct exposure by direct issue bonds to the 5 monoliners is 24 million as a total. We don't have any exposure to ACA, direct or indirect. The indirect exposure to high rated US municipalities via Tender Option Bond programs is 535 million. We have underlying backed by the five monoliners. That means that the monoliners are insurers although these municipalities, sorry the second lien to creditworthiness of each municipality. So we think that our exposure is limited and indirect and well diversified.

Talking of investment banking, their performance has been pretty good during the year, plus 39%. There has been a very good performance also in the principal investment area. That has been quite positive for us but also the financing has been pretty good.

And finally, talking of the underwriting portfolio, we are at 4.9 billion. 99% is Europe. As you know, 3 billion is alliance with and Valentino to one – alliance with Valentino. Also on that, we received many questions of why this is not marked to market. Our credit portfolio is in the banking book. But we have done the valuation is net of these, and so it is 98. We go through an impairment test every month. The credit stories are quite good. So we don't have any issue in this portfolio.

Purchase price allocation. In terms of process just to be clear, purchase price allocation is a process where there is a firm auditor that manages the process. It has been PriceWaterhouse. Then is a check with us and with our auditors. This is quite important. We made an adjustment on the loan portfolio of 600 million. We made an adjustment on Trevi of 500 million. There is a positive fair value adjustment on other owned securities, other assets and performing loans by 1.4. We have an adjustment, negative adjustment; the sign '+' is a negative; it's "a reduction" of the capital. The positive – the negative sign is an increase of capital. Liabilities for 200 million fair value adjustment on liabilities and accounting alignment, mainly legal cost and non-used holidays. Fiscal effect at 100 million; so in terms of total impact Core Tier 1 is zero basis point; it's rounding. The adjustment on the credit portfolio, I think that this was the main issue on which we were continuing to discuss, has been 1.1 billion, so the portfolio has been cleaned up.

Asset quality; Capitalia asset quality, we had this reduction in terms of net impaired loans and coverage ratio on impaired loans is also due to the PPA of 600 million, as we were talking before. So there has been a significant improvement of the coverage ratio.

The Trevi exposure is down to 1.370 billion. For the Trevi 1 and Trevi 2, we do expect to unwound the position though there are not any more bondholders; so during the year they will cut loose. It will come back on our books. It's important for us because in this way we'll reduce the cost of managing the vehicle in terms of external cost.

In Trevi 3, there are still external bondholders, so we will keep the vehicle. To date with this adjustment of 100 million and with a coverage ratio of 73% and collateralized exposure of 33%, we think that the Trevi topic is not anymore a topic for our discussion. UniCredit is managing the old portfolio. We have closed the joint venture with Goldman Sachs, so it's managed by our very efficient workout unit.

HVB is still reducing significantly that our portfolio. This is the last time we'll report on the RER portfolio. We have a 2.1 gross volume billion at the end of February. This is an estimation at the end of February. The net is in the range of 400 million. So we don't report anymore on the RER portfolio. Also, the special credit portfolio is going significantly down. This is quite important both in term of risk rated weighted assets because as you remember, this is the pro forma portfolio which is not positive in terms of value creation. So the fact that have been able to reduce by 8 billion since the creation is quite good in terms of funding where clearly this reduction is an important element. So we think that HVB has been very successful in managing these two items.

So the total net impaired loans at the group level went down by 3 billion, which is in our opinion very, very relevant. We are down by 75 basis points since December '06, which again is not bad at all; and the coverage ratio went up by 3%. So we are at 54.5%, which is a significant improvement in the year.

Cost of risk is stable. On the previous year, we had reduction quarter on quarter. As you can see, this is due mainly to Germany were we had very positive cash recovery, mainly in MIB and in Corporate. Austria, the reduction is due to the fact also that in '06, we had an exceptional write-off in the retail portfolio; so it went down quite significantly. But without the one-off the reduction is less relevant.

Capitalia Integration, we have three main areas. Business model, the integration of the former Capitalia network in our model is doing quite well. This is very, very important for us in terms of the homogenization of quality service for us and also for having the right efficiency in the activity of redesigning the portfolios of customers assigned to each of the portfolio managers. We had a significant reduction of the need for portfolio managers. That is quite important to be able to increase the number of new customers that we will be able to manage with the portfolio managers because we have bringing up people.

In terms of our restructuring, there is significant room for cost reduction of human resources, right-sizing. As we said, we have 7,800 people that accepted our early retirement plan. It is 14% of the Italian employee base, so it is quite a lot. The unification of back office, Central Functions, Product Factories, and IT is well ongoing. You will see the plan for the migration. By the end of October, everything will be realized. So you remember that we have signed the contract the 1st of October so it's 13 months to complete the restructuring of 2,000 branches in the last 13 months I think is quite good.

We have significant growth related to the alignment of productivity and penetration gap in Retail and Corporate. So we see some numbers. First of all, in terms of aligning the business model, what we have already done, we have done the Private virtual carve-out and the Corporate Big Bang, so banking for corporate customers. We have redesigned Bipop, Banca di Roma, and Banco di Sicilia in order to have the private banking customer as a corporate customer already managed by people that in spite of the fact that they are still in these banks where there is a close connection with the private banking people and the corporate people. Quite clearly, this has been done with a strong analysis in terms of compliance, which is quite important for us. This is the right way to have them immediately in alignment in terms of service model and also to avoid problems in terms of competition on the corporate customer mainly because as you can imagine, where a corporate customer followed by more than one bank of the group can create issues in terms of a service model.

The business real carve out will be realized the first of November. As I said before by the end of October, we will have all the migration so we do expect to have the merger and the spin-off of the different activities.

2,000 people already went out. 2,800 are expected to leave the company in '08; 1,600 in '09; and 1,400 in '10. Again, we already said that but I think that the fact that we have been able to add 2,000 people leaving with the retirement window of the 1st of October at the same day we signed the agreement is something exceptional. I think it's very important because to give an idea on the effect, we are apparently quite capable in managing the structure and process and so it always embarrassing to say something positive of the – but we have 2,000 people that are accepted the early retirement plan before the signing of the contract of the merger, these things that we have negotiated with the trade unions. We have agreed with them. We have sent out the invitation letter to the eligible employees. They have accepted and it was pretty complex.

We have the integration of Bipop Carire in the second quarter, Banca di Roma if I remember correctly the Ferragosto day, Banco di Sicilia by the last weekend of October. We need a weekend for our integration for Banca di Roma, which is the larger bank; we use three days. It's quite important that these things are very well planned because you have very small windows for realizing the integration. But by end of October, everything will be completely realized.

In term of synergies, we do expect to have higher synergies both as a total; here we are talking of cost synergies, and in '08. These are more or less as the same amount that we have been able to anticipate at the beginning and is mainly related to staff costs but also other costs. So 76% of the hire reduction, 120 million in '08, is staff costs due to the exits we have seen before.

Customers, here is a short snapshot on retail. We have significant room for improvement both in small business and in the household areas in small business. We have significant room for increasing the number of customers with credit lines, which is quite important because at the end, it is a long base which creates the most significant profitability area for the small business activity and also there is very significant room for improving the capability of acquiring new customers.
